channel.title: Good computer?
channel.description: [IMG]http://i161.photobucket.com/albums/t231/sanga282/sepcs.jpg[/img] A friend of mine linked me to this and these are the stats for a £400 computer, it doesn't have a monitor or an OS but i can factor in those costs myself. The one i wanted was 500 and had 8gb RAM and 2 of the graphics cards but its unavailable as of current so what do you think worth the cash ?

item.title: Good computer?
item.dc:creator: @nathanator22 nathanator22
item.description:
@nathanator22 wrote:

Cheese_Police:

the 64 bit release of xp is very flawed, it breaks compatibility with a lot of applications. if you’re going to get 64 bit windows, you are better off with getting vista.

First i want to say, i agree with getting vista. I have Home premium on my Toshiba laptop and it works great. However, i built a computer for my friend and put winXp x64 on it simply because he doesn’t like vista, and he hasn’t had any problems with any games or any other programs at all. Just wondering, what programs have you found that don’t work on it?

And back on topic, i would say you are definitely better building it custom. It would be a lot cheaper even if you bought the same parts.

Read full topic

item.title: Good computer?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:6, topic:270299”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=356748.msg2729028#msg2729028 date=1238569459]
If the UK has some equivalent to Nz’s Trademe, then I would recommend browsing around for a few months to find the lowest prices for parts and buy the computer part by part. might take half a year to get all the parts needed to build a comp, but you will end up getting it for pretty cheap. (Get mobo and ram first. Graphics last.)
[/quote]
I know what you mean, I decided against this in the end im gonna build one myself without them selecting the parts for me, going with an Intel Quad Core Q8200, then depending on how much cash i might get a triple channel DDR3 supporting motherboard, more RAM is fun![/quote]I agree! My 8gb will last a while, although my mobo supports 16gb

Read full topic

If the UK has some equivalent to Nz’s Trademe, then I would recommend browsing around for a few months to find the lowest prices for parts and buy the computer part by part. might take half a year to get all the parts needed to build a comp, but you will end up getting it for pretty cheap. xEnt:

this is a shit computer for the price.

Really?

item.title: Good computer?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

The ultimate question really, is where you can shop from. If you are able to purchase from newegg, this is a shit computer for the price.

It’s really hard to say, but the CPU is shit (the older phenoms), the video card is shit (they write SLI to make people think it comes with 2? when all it means is that it supports SLI rofl)

But like i said, this might be good value wherever you come from, and if you don’t know how to assemble a computer from scratch. But if you can newegg and know how to put a PC together, this is junk.

Read full topic
